message.content:
cs.CV, cs.LG, cs.AI, cs.NE, cs.MM 

The paper deals with the problem of predicting human perceptual similarity, which is a core topic in computer vision. The paper leverages representations learned from a diverse set of visual tasks to predict perceptual similarity, which is a common approach in computer vision and machine learning. Therefore, the most likely sub-category is cs.CV (Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition). The paper also discusses the broader context of emergent visual capabilities and their implications on the course of machine-vision research, which suggests that it may also belong to cs.LG (Machine Learning) and cs.AI (Artificial Intelligence). Additionally, the paper uses simple feature concatenation without any further learning, which is a common technique in neural networks, suggesting that it may also belong to cs.NE (Neural and Evolutionary Computing). Finally, the paper evaluates its approach on the challenging Totally-Looks-Like (TLL) benchmark, which is a dataset of image pairs that look similar but are not identical, suggesting that it may also belong to cs.MM (Multimedia).
